Award.AwardTitle: Redox Behavior and Chemical Reactivity of Heme-HNOx Complexes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Structure, Dynamics & Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division at the NSF supports the collaborative research between Professor George B. Richter-Addo at the University of Oklahoma (OU) and Professor Michael J. Shaw at Southern Illinois University Edwardsville (SIUE). The overall goal of this research is to prepare and characterize reactive biological intermediates of relevance to the global nitrogen cycle and human health. Emphasis is placed on the fundamental iron-mediated chemistry of the nitrogen oxides (NOx) that have been implicated in various processes such as atmospheric pollution, blood pressure control in humans, and in bacterial survival or death. Although the simplest NOx species, namely nitric oxide (NO) is known to regulate normal blood pressure, not much is known about the generation and action of related species such as nitroxyl (HNO) and nitrosoalkanes (RNO). This collaborative group has joint expertise in chemical synthesis and electroanalytical chemistry, and combines a Ph.D. environment (at OU) and a primarily undergraduate environment (at SIUE) to provide high-level training to a diverse group of students. Outreach activities involving inner-city high school students from low-income and disadvantaged backgrounds are an essential component of this project.

Heme-HNO and -hyponitrite compounds are important intermediates in the biological pathways of the overall global nitrogen cycle. For example, bacteria convert the diatomic vasodilator molecule NO to nitrous oxide via a hyponitrite intermediate using a di-iron active site, whereas fungi perform a similar NO-to-nitrous oxide reaction using a mono-iron active site. The fungal reaction involves initial hydride attack at a ferric heme nitrosyl to generate a heme-HNO intermediate. This research team recently succeeded in generating a synthetic model system to demonstrate heme-HNO formation via hydride attack on a ferric heme nitrosyl, which provided an appropriate framework to determine factors that promote further reactions of these heme-HNO species. In this project, the aims are to: (i) prepare a representative range of ferric heme nitrosyls, (ii) explore reactions involving nucleophilic attack at the bound nitrosyls to generate heme-XNO derivatives (X = H, alkyl/aryl), (iii) determine the redox behavior of these species especially those involving proton-coupled electron transfers, (iv) prepare heme model-hyponitrite compounds and establish their reactivity patterns, and (v) prepare the related heme model-NONOate derivatives to determine the factors that promote decomposition of these species to generate the vasodilator NO molecule.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bacteria and fungi have enzymes that process nitrogen. While the majority of nitrogen on earth is trapped in the atmosphere as the unreactive "dinitrogen" gas, enzymes in various organisms are able to utilize metal ions in specific biomolecules to perform rather intricate chemistry on nitrogen to convert it into other forms that can be assimilated by plants (e.g., nitrate, of relevance to agriculture) or even into molecules that are toxic and/or carcinogenic. Several of these bacteria and fungal enzymes utilize "heme" centers that contain the metal iron (Fe). One of the central nitrogen-containing species resulting from such nitrogen processing is the diatomic molecule nitric oxide (NO). This molecule, in concert with heme Fe, is a primary signaling agent in humans for normal blood pressure control. Other forms of processed nitrogen of great interest are nitroxyl (HNO) and nitrous oxide, the latter being a powerful greenhouse gas. In this collaborative project between a Ph.D. institution (OU) and a primarily undergraduate institution (SIUE Edwardsville), we applied fundamental chemistry principles to unravel how fungal enzymes utilize Fe to convert the molecule NO into its derivatives HNO and the greenhouse gas nitrous oxide.

 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: To better understand how NO binds to fungal heme enzymes, we synthesized and characterized the first representative set of stable model ferric heme-NO compounds. These model heme-NO compounds were then used to generate their heme-HNO derivatives through attack of the bound NO molecule by hydride (i.e., mimicking the method used by fungi). Importantly, we also showed that these heme-HNO compounds could be attacked by added NO to form nitrous oxide via the formation of an N-N bond. Our NSF-sponsored work represented the first successful chemical validation of this greenhouse gas generation by fungi.

In addition, we demonstrated a viable reaction pathway utilized by bacteria for the conversion of NO into nitrous oxide.  Bacteria that perform this conversion utilize an enzyme containing heme Fe and a non-heme Fe center in close proximity, but it was unclear what the role of this di-Fe configuration was. We demonstrated, using a combination of chemical synthesis, spectroscopy, computational chemistry, and X-ray crystallography, that the role of the second "non-heme Fe center" was to provide a site for the polarization of the heme-NO unit to render the NO susceptible to attack by another NO molecule to create an N-N bond.  Our work represented the first experimental support for the proposed cis:b3 mechanism for bacterial NO detoxification.

The way a molecule such as NO binds to a heme center in a biomolecule determines its subsequent chemical reactivity and ultimately how it will be metabolized. We probed such NO binding in detail with the muscle protein myoglobin (Mb). Using a combination of ultaviolet-visible spectroscopy and crystallography, we demonstrated unique NO conformational preferences in the MbNO proteins that likely have consequences for its varied biological action. These binding differences were further substantiated by advanced computational chemistry methods.

Of particular interest to this project was to determine the electrochemical properties of such heme-NO model compounds. Chemical reactions, by their very nature, depend on movements and rearrangements of electrons in the reacting molecules. We developed improved electrochemical methodology that utilized efficient consideration of uncompensated resistance for the accurate extraction of reaction kinetics and thermodynamic parameters for electron transfer events. Development of such methodology is crucial if we are to obtain a better understanding of the chemical properties of such heme-NO systems.

 

BROADER IMPACTS: This collaborative grant involving an R1 institution (OU, the PI) and a PUI institution (SIUE, co-PI) allowed us to modernize our educational tools for the training of students. We completely overhauled and designed a new freshman General Chemistry course for initial implementation at the PI's institution. This course adopts an "atoms first" approach but focuses on a deep understanding of chemical principles that drive event in the natural world, and links chemistry with biochemistry and physics. The course materials have been shared with the co-PI and faculty at 4 other institutions. Conversely, the co-PI's development of electrochemistry educational materials have been shared with, and utilized by, the PI in both undergraduate and graduate courses.

The PI participated actively in summer Sooner Upward Bound programs for high school students from disadvantaged communities in the Oklahoma City area, and in mentoring first year undergraduate researchers in his home institution's First Year Research Experience (FYRE) program. The co-PI joined the Board of Directors of the Science Circle Foundation and developed eight online virtual lectures (available on YouTube) on popular science topics through its Science Circle organization in the virtual world Second Life (SL). SL offers a rich multiplayer flexible online environment, especially for individuals with disabilities. 

Ten graduate students and ten undergraduates participated in this collaborative grant, as did two postdoctoral fellows. Several peer-reviewed manuscripts were published, and the work was disseminated at several regional, national, and international conferences.
